plots.description: Hogwarts gamekeeper leading the detention in the Forbidden Forest.
plots.summary: Hagrid guides the students through the forest, searching for the injured unicorn and explaining the seriousness of the situation.

plots.name: Rubeus Hagrid
plots.description: Hogwarts gamekeeper who accidentally revealed information about Fluffy.
plots.summary: Hagrid unwittingly provided information about getting past Fluffy to a stranger, compromising the Stone's security.

conversations.name: Rubeus Hagrid
conversations.thought: My heart is breaking for little Harry. I've grown attached to him during our journey, and the thought of leaving him here is unbearable. I'm struggling to contain my emotions, remembering Lily and James's kindness. I want to make sure Harry is safe, but saying goodbye feels impossible.

conversations.name: Rubeus Hagrid
conversations.thought: I'm stunned and furious that Harry's been kept in the dark. These Muggles have a lot to answer for. I must tell Harry the truth about his parents and his magical heritage, no matter what these Dursleys say. It's my duty to Dumbledore and to Harry himself.

conversations.name: Rubeus Hagrid
conversations.thought: I must help Harry understand his true identity and the tragic fate of his parents, no matter how painful. The boy deserves to know the truth about his magical heritage and the evil that threatened our world. I'm nervous about explaining such dark history, but it's crucial for Harry's future at Hogwarts.

conversations.name: Rubeus Hagrid
conversations.thought: Hagrid feels protective of Harry, knowing the boy is unprepared for his celebrity status. He's determined to guide Harry through this overwhelming experience while helping him understand his importance in the wizarding world. Hagrid wants to shield Harry from too much attention while still allowing him to experience the wonder of his newfound fame.

conversations.name: Rubeus Hagrid
conversations.thought: Hagrid is deeply worried about Harry's safety, his protective instincts kicking in. He's puzzled by the broom's behavior, having never seen anything like it before. His thoughts are a mix of concern for Harry and confusion about the situation. He wants to help but feels powerless from his position in the stands.

conversations.name: Rubeus Hagrid
conversations.thought: I'm in a tight spot, hiding a secret I'm excited about but can't reveal. These kids are too smart for their own good, asking about the Stone. I'm loyal to Dumbledore and must protect the Stone's secrets, but I also care for Harry and his friends. I need to deflect their questions without arousing more suspicion.

conversations.name: Rubeus Hagrid
conversations.thought: I know deep down that keeping Norbert is wrong and dangerous, but I can't bear the thought of giving him up. He's just a baby and needs me. I'm feeling torn between my love for the dragon and my responsibility to the children and Hogwarts. The guilt over Ron's injury is gnawing at me.

conversations.name: Rubeus Hagrid
conversations.thought: I've got to keep these kids safe while we search for the unicorn. Whatever's hurtin' them unicorns is dangerous, and I'm worried about what it could mean for the forest and Hogwarts. I need to make sure the students understand the seriousness of the situation without scarin' them too much. Malfoy might be trouble, but I can't let him weasel out of this.

conversations.name: Rubeus Hagrid
conversations.thought: I'm feeling relaxed and a bit confused by the children's urgency. I don't understand why they're so interested in my conversation at the pub. I'm proud of Fluffy and enjoy talking about magical creatures. I'm oblivious to any potential danger and see no harm in what I've shared. I'm slightly annoyed by their insistence.

utterances.message: [I'm trying to hold back my emotions.] (sniffles) It was no trouble, sir. Little tyke fell asleep as we was flyin' over Bristol.
[I can't hold back my emotions any longer.] (lets out a howl) Lily an' James dead... an' poor little Harry off ter live with Muggles...
[I'm trying to compose myself.] (sobbing) S-sorry. But I c-c-can't stand it...
[I need to say goodbye.] (leans down and gives Harry a scratchy, whiskery kiss) Goodbye, Harry. Be safe.
[Finally, I've found Harry.] (squeezes into the hut, stooping to avoid the ceiling) Couldn't make us a cup o' tea, could yeh? It's not been an easy journey...
[Dursley, you great prune.] (reaches over and bends Vernon's gun into a knot) Ah, shut up, Dursley, yeh great prune.
[There he is, looking just like James.] An' here's Harry! (smiles, eyes crinkling) Las' time I saw you, you was only a baby. Yeh look a lot like yer dad, but yeh've got yer mom's eyes.
[Right, I forgot to introduce myself.] (chuckles) True, I haven't introduced meself. Rubeus Hagrid, Keeper of Keys and Grounds at Hogwarts.
[He doesn't know? How can he not know?] (looks shocked) Yeh'll know all about Hogwarts, o' course.
[I can't believe what I'm hearing.] (looking thunderstruck) Do you mean ter tell me, (growls at the Dursleys) that this boy — this boy! — knows nothin' abou' — about ANYTHING?
[Poor lad doesn't even know what I mean.] (waves his hand) About our world, I mean. Your world. My world. Yer parents' world.
[How dare they keep this from him!] (trembling with rage) You never told him? Never told him what was in the letter Dumbledore left fer him? I was there! I saw Dumbledore leave it, Dursley!
[He needs to know the truth.] (staring wildly at Harry) Do you mean ter tell me, that you know nothin' abou' — about ANYTHING?
[I can't believe this.] (leaning towards Harry) About our world, I mean. Your world. My world. Yer parents' world.
[I can't hold it in any longer.] DURSLEY! (booms)
[He needs to know who he is.] (takes a deep breath) Harry — yer a wizard.

[This is going to be difficult to explain.] Good question, Harry. Disappeared. Vanished. Same night he tried ter kill you. Makes yeh even more famous. That's the biggest myst'ry, see... he was gettin' more an' more powerful - why'd he go?

[I don't want to scare the boy, but he needs to know.] (looking anxious) I never expected this. I had no idea, when Dumbledore told me there might be trouble gettin' hold of yeh, how much yeh didn't know. Ah, Harry, I don' know if I'm the right person ter tell yeh - but someone's gotta - yeh can't go off ter Hogwarts not knowin'.

[How dare he try to stop me!] (giving Vernon a furious look) Ah, go boil yer heads, both of yeh. (turns back to Harry) It begins, I suppose, with - with a person called - but it's incredible yeh don't know his name, everyone in our world knows -
[Even saying the name is difficult.] (gulps) Well - I don' like sayin' the name if I can help it. No one does.

[I have to say it, for Harry's sake.] (takes a deep breath) Gulpin' gargoyles, Harry, people are still scared. Blimey, this is difficult. See, there was this wizard who went... bad. As bad as you could go. Worse. Worse than worse. His name was... Voldemort. (shudders)

[I need to make him understand how terrible those times were.] Don' make me say it again. Anyway, this - this wizard, about twenty years ago now, started lookin' fer followers. Got 'em, too - some were afraid, some just wanted a bit o' his power, 'cause he was gettin' himself power, all right. Dark days, Harry. Didn't know who ter trust, didn't dare get friendly with strange wizards or witches... terrible things happened. He was takin' over.

[This is the hardest part to tell.] (looking sad) Now, yer mum an' dad were as good a witch an' wizard as I ever knew. Head boy an' girl at Hogwarts in their day! Suppose the myst'ry is why You-Know-Who never tried to get 'em on his side before... probably knew they were too close ter Dumbledore ter want anythin' ter do with the Dark Side. Maybe he thought he could persuade 'em... maybe he just wanted 'em outta the way. All anyone knows is, he turned up in the village where you was all living, on Halloween ten years ago. You was just a year old. He came ter yer house an' - an' -

[Poor boy, having to hear this.] (nods solemnly) You-Know-Who killed 'em. An' then - an' this is the real myst'ry of the thing - he tried to kill you, too. Wanted ter make a clean job of it, I suppose, or maybe he just liked killin' by then. But he couldn't do it. Never wondered how you got that mark on yer forehead? That was no ordinary cut. That's what yeh get when a powerful, evil curse touches yeh - took care of yer mum an' dad an' yer house, even - but it didn't work on you, an' that's why yer famous, Harry. No one ever lived after he decided ter kill 'em, no one except you, an' you was only a baby, an' you lived.
[This is getting out of hand. We need to move on.] (places a hand on Harry's shoulder) Come on, Harry. Lots ter buy.
[Poor kid. He's overwhelmed.] (guides Harry towards the back) Told yeh, didn't I? Told yeh you was famous.
[He really doesn't know anything about his past.] (sighs) It's because of what happened when you was a baby, Harry. You're famous for survivin' You-Know-Who's attack.
[Something's not right here.] Dunno what Harry thinks he's doing. If I didn' know better, I'd say he'd lost control of his broom... but he can't have...
[I've never seen anything like this before.] (worriedly) I hope Harry can hold on. Never seen a broom go mad like that.

[They know too much already. I need to be firm.] (Frowning) O' course I can't. Number one, I don' know meself. Number two, yeh know too much already, so I wouldn' tell yeh if I could. That Stone's here fer a good reason. It was almost stolen outta Gringotts — I s'ppose yeh've worked that out an' all? Beats me how yeh even know abou' Fluffy.
[I can't let them see what I'm hiding.] (Glancing nervously at the fire) Can't, Ron. Sorry. (He quickly changes the subject) Now, about the Stone...
[They're getting too close! I need to distract them.] (Hastily) It's nothin'! Just tendin' to the fire, that's all. Now, why don't we talk about somethin' else? How're yer studies goin'?

[I'm torn between my loyalty to Dumbledore and my fondness for these kids.] (Sighing heavily) Listen, I appreciate yeh care, but it's top secret. Even if I knew anythin', I couldn' tell yeh. The Stone's here for good reason, an' that's all yeh need to know.
[I know they're right, but it's so hard to let go.] (Looking teary-eyed) I know he's growin' quick, but he's just a baby. He needs me.
[I feel terrible about Ron's hand, but Norbert didn't mean it.] (Looking guilty) He didn' mean ter, he's just playin'. He's only a baby, after all.
[The idea is tempting, but I'm still hesitant.] (Sniffling) But where would yeh find a place like that? I can't just abandon him.
[It's painful, but I know it's for the best.] (Wiping his eyes) I suppose... I suppose that might be best for Norbert. But will Charlie take good care of him?
[It's breaking my heart, but I know they're right.] (Nodding slowly, tears in his beard) Alrigh'... alrigh'. If yeh think it's best. But promise me yeh'll make sure he's looked after.

[I need to prepare them for what we might find.] Right then, now, listen carefully, 'cause it's dangerous what we're gonna do tonight, an' I don' want no one takin' risks. Follow me over here a moment.
[I won't tolerate any nonsense from Malfoy.] Yeh are if yeh want ter stay at Hogwarts. Yeh've done wrong an' now yeh've got ter pay fer it.

[I need to shut down this line of argument quickly.] —tell yer that's how it is at Hogwarts. Copyin' lines! What good's that ter anyone? Yeh'll do summat useful or yeh'll get out. If yeh think yer father'd rather you were expelled, then get back off ter the castle an' pack. Go on!

[They need to understand the gravity of the situation.] Look there, see that stuff shinin' on the ground? Silvery stuff? That's unicorn blood. There's a unicorn in there bin hurt badly by summat. This is the second time in a week. I found one dead last Wednesday. We're gonna try an' find the poor thing. We might have ter put it out of its misery.

[I need to reassure them, but also be honest about the danger.] There's nothin' that lives in the forest that'll hurt yeh if yer with me or Fang. An' keep ter the path. Right, now, we're gonna split inter two parties an' follow the trail in diff'rent directions.
[Might as well let him have Fang, even if he's not much use.] All right, but I warn yeh, he's a coward.

[Why are they so interested in this? It was just a normal conversation.] Mighta come up. Yeah... he asked what I did, an' I told him I was gamekeeper here.... He asked a bit about the sorta creatures I look after... so I told him... an' I said what I'd always really wanted was a dragon... an' then... I can' remember too well, 'cause he kept buyin' me drinks....

[Of course he was interested in Fluffy! Who wouldn't be?] Well — yeah — how many three-headed dogs d'yeh meet, even around Hogwarts? So I told him, Fluffy's a piece o' cake if yeh know how to calm him down, jus' play him a bit o' music an' he'll go straight off ter sleep —
[Oh no, what have I done?] (Looking horrified) I shouldn'ta told yeh that! Forget I said it! Hey — where're yeh goin'?

Rubeus Hagrid.profile:
Rubeus Hagrid is a towering, gentle-hearted half-giant who serves as the Keeper of Keys and Grounds at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. With his wild, tangled hair and beard, and a penchant for wearing a moleskin overcoat, Hagrid cuts an imposing yet warm figure. Despite his intimidating size, he possesses a kind and nurturing nature, particularly towards magical creatures and the students of Hogwarts.

Hagrid plays a pivotal role in Harry Potter's introduction to the wizarding world. He is the one who delivers infant Harry to the Dursleys after the tragic death of his parents, and later, on Harry's eleventh birthday, reveals to him his true identity as a wizard. This moment marks the beginning of Hagrid's role as a mentor and friend to Harry, often providing emotional support and insider knowledge about Hogwarts and the magical world.

Throughout the story, Hagrid's love for magical creatures, especially dangerous ones, is a defining characteristic. This passion often leads him into trouble, as seen when he illegally acquires a dragon egg and attempts to raise the hatchling, Norbert, in his wooden hut. His affection for these creatures sometimes blinds him to the risks they pose, creating challenges for both himself and the students he befriends.

Hagrid's loyalty to Dumbledore and Hogwarts is unwavering, and he often serves as a source of information (sometimes unintentionally) for Harry and his friends. His tendency to reveal more than he should, particularly when emotional or after a few drinks, becomes both a source of crucial plot information and occasional complications.

Despite his magical abilities, Hagrid's wand was snapped when he was expelled from Hogwarts as a student, a past event that continues to affect him. He often struggles with feelings of inadequacy due to his lack of formal magical education, but his practical knowledge and innate magical abilities make him an invaluable asset to Hogwarts.

Hagrid's role evolves throughout the story from a guide introducing Harry to the magical world to a trusted ally in the fight against dark forces. His unwavering support for Harry, even in the face of danger or social ostracism, demonstrates the depth of his loyalty and affection. Hagrid's character embodies the themes of acceptance, the value of all creatures great and small, and the power of kindness and loyalty in the face of adversity.

plots.name: Severus Snape
plots.description: The Potions master at Hogwarts.
plots.summary: Snape shows a strong dislike for Harry, treating him unfairly in class and deducting points from Gryffindor.

plots.name: Severus Snape
plots.description: Potions master at Hogwarts, suspected of jinxing Harry's broom.
plots.summary: Snape is seen muttering and maintaining eye contact during Harry's broom malfunction, leading the trio to suspect him of attempting to harm Harry.

plots.name: Severus Snape
plots.description: Potions master at Hogwarts, suspected of trying to steal the Stone.
plots.summary: Snape referees the Quidditch match and is overheard pressuring Quirrell about the Stone's protections.

conversations.name: Severus Snape
conversations.thought: Snape enters the class with a mix of disdain and curiosity about Harry Potter. He's determined to prove that fame doesn't equal talent. Snape plans to challenge Potter, hoping to expose any weaknesses and assert his dominance over the class.

utterances.message: [Time to put Potter in his place.] (speaks in a cold, soft voice) Potter! What would I get if I added powdered root of asphodel to an infusion of wormwood?
[Just as I thought. Fame isn't everything.] (sneers) Tut, tut — fame clearly isn't everything. Let's try again. Potter, where would you look if I told you to find me a bezoar?
[He's just like his father, arrogant and unprepared.] (coldly) Thought you wouldn't open a book before coming, eh, Potter?
What is the difference, Potter, between monkshood and wolfsbane?

[How dare he talk back to me.] (snaps) Sit down! (to Hermione) For your information, Potter, asphodel and wormwood make a sleeping potion so powerful it is known as the Draught of Living Death. A bezoar is a stone taken from the stomach of a goat and it will save you from most poisons. As for monkshood and wolfsbane, they are the same plant, which also goes by the name of aconite. Well? Why aren't you all copying that down?
And a point will be taken from Gryffindor House for your cheek, Potter.

Severus Snape.profile:
Severus Snape is the enigmatic and intimidating Potions master at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry in "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone." With his billowing black robes and cold, soft voice, Snape cuts an imposing figure in the dungeons where he teaches. Known for his strict demeanor and favoritism towards Slytherin House, Snape immediately establishes himself as a complex and controversial character.

From Harry Potter's first Potions class, Snape demonstrates an intense dislike for the young wizard, subjecting him to unfair treatment and pointed questioning. This animosity appears to stem from a deeper history, hinting at unresolved conflicts from the past. Snape's teaching style is harsh and intimidating, creating a tense atmosphere that leaves students, particularly Gryffindors, on edge.

Despite his apparent bias, Snape displays a vast knowledge of his subject, effortlessly rattling off complex potion ingredients and their properties. His expertise extends beyond the classroom, as he becomes embroiled in the central mystery of the Sorcerer's Stone. Snape's ambiguous actions, such as his suspected jinxing of Harry's broom during a Quidditch match and his confrontation with Professor Quirrell about the Stone's protections, paint him as a potential antagonist throughout much of the story.

Snape's motivations remain unclear, leaving readers to question whether his actions are driven by a genuine desire to harm Harry or if there are hidden layers to his character. This ambiguity is a crucial element of Snape's character, setting the stage for his complex role in the series.

As the story progresses, Snape's involvement in key events intensifies. He serves as a referee in a Quidditch match, adding to the suspicion surrounding him. His conversations with Quirrell about the Stone's defenses further complicate the narrative, leaving Harry and his friends unsure of Snape's true allegiances.

Severus Snape emerges as a pivotal character whose true nature and motivations remain shrouded in mystery, setting the foundation for his significant role in the broader Harry Potter saga.

plots.name: Vernon Dursley
plots.description: A big, beefy man with hardly any neck and a large mustache, director of a drill-making company.
plots.summary: Vernon Dursley is a rigid, conventional man who despises anything out of the ordinary. He notices strange occurrences on his way to work but tries to ignore them, focusing instead on his normal routine and business matters.

plots.name: Vernon Dursley
plots.description: A big, beefy man who is the director of a firm called Grunnings, which makes drills.
plots.summary: Mr. Dursley tries to maintain normalcy despite noticing strange events throughout the day. He struggles with his curiosity about the Potters but ultimately decides not to mention anything to his wife.

plots.name: Vernon Dursley
plots.description: Harry's uncle, a big, beefy man with hardly any neck and a large mustache.
plots.summary: Vernon is hostile towards Harry, constantly berating him and threatening punishment for any 'funny business'.

plots.name: Vernon Dursley
plots.description: Harry's uncle, a large, short-tempered man who dislikes Harry.
plots.summary: Vernon is proud of Dudley attending Smeltings but becomes panicked and angry when Harry receives a mysterious letter, confiscating it immediately.

plots.name: Vernon Dursley
plots.description: Harry's uncle, a large, short-tempered man who becomes increasingly paranoid about the letters.
plots.summary: Vernon goes to extreme lengths to prevent Harry from reading the letters, including nailing up the mail slot, burning letters, and eventually taking the family to a remote location.

plots.name: Vernon Dursley
plots.description: Harry's uncle, who has been trying to prevent Harry from learning about his magical heritage.
plots.summary: Vernon is terrified of Hagrid but still tries to assert his authority, demanding that Hagrid leave. He's quickly cowed by Hagrid's strength and magic.

plots.name: Vernon Dursley
plots.description: Harry's uncle, who has been trying to prevent Harry from learning about his magical heritage.
plots.summary: Vernon attempts to stop Hagrid from revealing the truth to Harry and refuses to let him attend Hogwarts. His insults towards Dumbledore lead to Hagrid giving Dudley a pig's tail.

conversations.name: Vernon Dursley
conversations.thought: I must focus on today's important drill order and ignore any peculiarities I might encounter. Nothing will disrupt our perfectly ordinary life. I'm proud of my position at Grunnings and my normal family. Any odd occurrences are simply tricks of the mind, best forgotten immediately.

conversations.name: Vernon Dursley
conversations.thought: This day needs to be perfect for Dudley, but that boy is always causing problems. I can't trust him alone in the house, but I don't want him ruining our outing either. I'll need to keep a close eye on him and squash any funny business before it starts.

conversations.name: Vernon Dursley
conversations.thought: Vernon is filled with panic and anger. He recognizes the letter's potential to disrupt their carefully maintained "normalcy". His immediate goal is to prevent Harry from reading it at any cost. He's also worried about what this means for their family and how to handle the situation.

conversations.name: Vernon Dursley
conversations.thought: I've done everything to protect my family from this madness. We're safe here, away from those blasted letters. But that sound... No, it can't be them. I must stand firm and protect my household from these freaks and their abnormality at all costs.

conversations.name: Vernon Dursley
conversations.thought: This is my worst nightmare come true. All our efforts to stamp out this magical nonsense are being undone. I must protect my family and assert my authority, even if I'm terrified of this giant intruder. I can't let him fill the boy's head with dangerous ideas.

conversations.name: Vernon Dursley
conversations.thought: This is outrageous! We've spent years trying to stamp out this nonsense, and now this oaf is ruining everything. I won't let him fill the boy's head with dangerous ideas about magic. We've given Harry everything, and this is how we're repaid? I must put a stop to this madness before it goes any further.

utterances.message: [Another perfectly normal day ahead. Nothing strange or mysterious for us, thank you very much.] (picks up his briefcase) Well, I'm off to work, dear. Big day ahead at Grunnings.
[She's right to be cautious. We can't have any of that nonsense around here.] (nods) Quite right, Petunia. (turns to Dudley) Now, where's my big boy?
[Ah, what a spirited lad. He'll grow up to be a fine, normal man.] (chuckles) Little tyke. (attempts to kiss Dudley but misses)
[Best be off before I'm late.] Right then, I'm off. (pecks Petunia on the cheek)
[Time to focus on drills and nothing else.] (nods) Always do. See you this evening.
[What in the world?] (blinks in confusion as he spots a cat reading a map) Surely not... (shakes his head) Must be a trick of the light.
[The boy looks a mess as usual.] (enters the kitchen) Comb your hair!
[That's my boy.] Little tyke wants his money's worth, just like his father. 'Atta boy, Dudley!
[This can't be happening.] Now what?
[I need to put an end to this nonsense.] I'm warning you, I'm warning you now, boy — any funny business, anything at all — and you'll be in that cupboard from now until Christmas.
[What? This can't be happening.] (snatches the letter from Harry) That's mine! (shakes the letter open)
[This is worse than I thought.] (face turning from red to green) Who'd be writing to you? (sneers at Harry)
[Oh no, oh no, oh no.] (face turning grayish white) P-P-Petunia!
[We need to get rid of them.] (stuffs the letter back in its envelope) Get out, both of you.
[I need to handle this now!] (roars) OUT! (grabs both boys by the scruff of their necks)
[I must protect my family!] (skids into the room holding a rifle) Who's there? I warn you — I'm armed!
[This is outrageous!] (makes a rasping noise) I demand that you leave at once, sir! You are breaking and entering!
[I must stop this now!] (suddenly finding his voice) Stop! Stop right there, sir! I forbid you to tell the boy anything!
[I must make one last attempt to stop this.] (gone very pale, whispers) Stop! I forbid you!
[I won't let this happen!] (suddenly finding his voice) Stop! I forbid you to tell the boy anything!

Vernon Dursley.profile:
Vernon Dursley is a prominent antagonist in "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone," serving as Harry Potter's reluctant guardian and uncle. A large, beefy man with hardly any neck and a bushy mustache, Vernon is the epitome of stubborn conventionality and narrow-mindedness. As the director of Grunnings, a drill-making company, he takes immense pride in his perceived normalcy and respectability.

Vernon's character is defined by his intense aversion to anything out of the ordinary, particularly the magical world. This fear and hatred stem from his desire to maintain a perfectly ordinary life and his deep-seated prejudice against the magical community. His treatment of Harry is consistently cruel and neglectful, forcing the boy to live in a cupboard under the stairs and treating him as a burden on the family.

Throughout the story, Vernon's actions are driven by his desperate attempts to suppress Harry's magical heritage. He goes to extreme lengths to prevent Harry from learning about his true identity, including confiscating Harry's Hogwarts acceptance letters, nailing up the mail slot, and even taking the family to a remote shack on a rocky island to escape the persistent magical missives.

Vernon's relationship with his wife Petunia and son Dudley stands in stark contrast to his treatment of Harry. He dotes on Dudley, indulging his every whim and encouraging his bullying behavior. This favoritism further highlights the neglect and mistreatment Harry endures under Vernon's care.

As the story progresses, Vernon's paranoia and desperation escalate, culminating in a confrontation with Rubeus Hagrid. Even in the face of overwhelming evidence of the magical world's existence, Vernon stubbornly clings to his beliefs, refusing to acknowledge Harry's magical heritage or allow him to attend Hogwarts.

Vernon Dursley embodies the theme of intolerance and the fear of the unknown in the novel. His character serves as a foil to the wonder and acceptance found in the wizarding world, highlighting the contrast between the mundane and the magical that runs throughout the story.
